cluster_classes.class_description: Defensive behavioral adaptations in which caterpillars visually blend into their environment, including general background matching and specific mimicry of plant parts such as twigs and leaves.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Some caterpillars ... mimic the appearance of twigs or leaves to camouflage themselves from predators.

members.entity_description: Defensive strategy where caterpillars visually blend into surroundings to avoid predators.
Caterpillar camouflage strategy where individuals resemble twigs.
Caterpillar camouflage strategy in which individuals resemble leaves.

cluster_classes.class_description: Anatomical defensive structures on caterpillars, such as spines and hairs, that provide physical protection against predators and other threats.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Some caterpillars have spines or hairs for protection... protective adaptations.

members.entity_description: Defensive protrusions on some caterpillars used as protection against threats.
Hair-like structures on some caterpillars providing physical protection.
Combined defensive structures on caterpillars used to protect them from threats.

cluster_classes.class_description: Behaviors of caterpillars specifically related to consuming plant leaves as a primary food source.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars feeding on plant leaves as their main activity and food source.

members.entity_description: Primary caterpillar activity of consuming plant leaves for nutrition.

cluster_classes.class_description: Physical plant parts (e.g., leaves, stems, twigs) that serve as environmental structures or visual backgrounds for caterpillar behavior and camouflage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Leaves, stems, and twigs are plant parts used as background or attachment points.

members.entity_description: Plant leaves that are visually imitated by certain caterpillars for concealment.
Plant stem that serves as an attachment point for the caterpillar before forming a chrysalis.
Small plant branches whose appearance is mimicked by some caterpillars.

cluster_classes.class_description: Plant leaves considered as physical structures used by caterpillars for egg-laying, feeding sites, and chrysalis attachment.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars feeding on plant leaves as their main activity and food source.

members.entity_description: Plant leaves that serve as sites for egg-laying, feeding by caterpillars, and attachment for chrysalis formation.

args.justification: Camouflage, twig mimicry, and leaf mimicry are defensive behaviors; assigning a broader class_group 'Caterpillar Defense Mechanisms' aligns this behavioral defense class with other caterpillar defense-related classes.

Spines and hairs are anatomical defenses; grouping this anatomical defense class with the camouflage behavior class under 'Caterpillar Defense Mechanisms' reflects their shared defensive function while keeping them as separate structure/behavior classes.

args.new_name: Plant Structures as Caterpillar Environmental Context
args.new_description: Physical plant parts (e.g., leaves, stems, twigs) that serve as environmental structures, visual backgrounds, or attachment points in caterpillar life stages (including camouflage and chrysalis formation).
args.justification: This class currently mixes camouflage background structures (leaves, twigs) with a chrysalis-attachment stem; broadening the name/description and moving it to a habitat-oriented class_group clarifies it as general environmental plant structures used by caterpillars.

args.new_description: Plant structures (such as leaves and stems) used by caterpillars and butterflies as physical substrates for egg-laying, feeding, and chrysalis attachment.
args.justification: The existing class is conceptually about plant surfaces as substrate, and expanding from just leaves to general plant structures (leaves, stems, etc.) and aligning the class_group with other habitat-focused plant-structure classes yields a clearer, more reusable substrate class.

Entity 'stem' is described as an attachment point for the chrysalis, matching the substrate/habitat role of 'Plant Structures as Caterpillar Substrate' rather than the camouflage-focused context of the original class.

Refining the class_type_hint to 'Feeding Behavior' keeps this behavioral class distinct from habitat/structure and defense classes while correctly situating it within caterpillar–plant interaction behaviors.

executed_decisions.justification: Camouflage, twig mimicry, and leaf mimicry are defensive behaviors; assigning a broader class_group 'Caterpillar Defense Mechanisms' aligns this behavioral defense class with other caterpillar defense-related classes.

Spines and hairs are anatomical defenses; grouping this anatomical defense class with the camouflage behavior class under 'Caterpillar Defense Mechanisms' reflects their shared defensive function while keeping them as separate structure/behavior classes.
